☰

This homework builds on the material in the notes on neural networks up through and including section 6 on loss functions.

In particular, in this homework we consider neural networks with multiple layers. Each layer has multiple inputs and outputs, and can be broken down into two parts:

  • A linear module that implements a linear transformation: zj=(∑i=1mxiwi,j)+w0jz_j = (\sum^{m}_{i=1} x_i w_{i,j}) + {w_0}_jzj​=(∑i=1m​xi​wi,j​)+w0​j​ specified by a weight matrix WWW and a bias vector W0W_0W0​. The output is [z1,…,zn]T[z_1, \ldots, z_n]^T[z1​,…,zn​]T.
  • An activation module that applies an activation function to the outputs of the linear module for some activation function fff, such as Tanh or ReLU in the hidden layers or Softmax (see below) at the output layer. We write the output as: : [f(z1),…,f(zm)]T[f(z_1), \ldots, f(z_m)]^T[f(z1​),…,f(zm​)]T, although technically, for some activation functions such as softmax, each output will depend on all the ziz_izi​, not just one.

We will use the following notation for quantities in a network:

  • Inputs to the network are x1,…,xdx_1, \ldots, x_dx1​,…,xd​.
  • Number of layers is LLL
  • There are mlm^lml inputs to layer lll
  • There are nl=ml+1n^l = m^{l+1}nl=ml+1 outputs from layer lll
  • The weight matrix for layer lll is WlW^lWl, an ml×nlm^l \times n^lml×nl matrix, and the bias vector (offset) is W0lW_0^lW0l​, an nl×1n^l \times 1nl×1 vector
  • The outputs of the linear module for layer lll are known as pre-activation values and denoted zlz^lzl
  • The activation function at layer lll is fl(⋅)f^l(\cdot)fl(⋅)
  • Layer lll activations are al=[fl(z1l),…,fl(znll)]Ta^l = [f^l(z^l_1), \ldots, f^l(z^l_{n^l})]^Tal=[fl(z1l​),…,fl(znll​)]T
  • The output of the network is the values aL=[fL(z1L),…,fL(znLL)]Ta^L = [f^L(z^L_1), \ldots, f^L(z^L_{n^L})]^TaL=[fL(z1L​),…,fL(znLL​)]T
  • Loss function Loss(a,y)Loss(a, y)Loss(a,y) measures the loss of output values aaa when the target is yyy

1) Loss functions and output activations: classification

When doing classification, it's natural to think of the output values as being discrete: +1 and -1. But it is generally difficult to use optimization-based methods without somehow thinking of the outputs as being continuous (even though you will have to discretize when it's time to make a prediction).

1.1) Hinge loss, linear activation

When we looked at the SVM objective for classification, we did this:

  • Defined the output space to be R\mathbb{R}R
  • Developed the hinge loss function
    Loss(a,y)=Lh(ya)={0if ya &gt; 11−yaotherwiseLoss(a, y) = L_h(y a) = \begin{cases} 0 &amp; \text{if $y a$ &gt; 1}\\ 1 - ya &amp; \text{otherwise}\end{cases}Loss(a,y)=Lh​(ya)={01−ya​if ya > 1otherwise​
    where aaa is the continuous output (we're using aaa here to be consistent with the neural network terminology of activation) and yyy is the desired/target output
  • Tried to find parameters θ\thetaθ of our model to minimize loss summed over the training data

Consider a single "neuron" with a linear activation function; that is, where a1L=∑kwk,1Lxk+w0,1La_1^L = \sum_k w^L_{k,1} x_k + {w_{0,1}^L}a1L​=∑k​wk,1L​xk​+w0,1L​. In this case, we have L=1L = 1L=1 and fL(z)=zf^L(z) = zfL(z)=z.

1.1.A) Write a short program to compute the gradient of the loss function with respect to the weight vector (not the bias): ∇wLLoss(a1L,y)\nabla_{w^L} Loss(a_1^L, y)∇wL​Loss(a1L​,y) when Loss(a,y)=Lh(ya)Loss(a, y) = L_h(y a)Loss(a,y)=Lh​(ya).

  • x is a column vector
  • y is a number, a label
  • a is a number, an activation

It should return a column vector.

1
2
3
4
def hinge_loss_grad(x, y, a):
# https://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/4608/gradient-of-hinge-loss
return np.where(y*a < 1, -y*x, 0)

1.2) Log loss, sigmoidal activation

Another way to make the output for a classifier continuous is to make it be in the range (0,1)(0, 1)(0,1), which admits the interpretation of being the predicted probability that the example is positive. A convenient way to make the activation of a unit be in the range (0,1)(0, 1)(0,1) is to use a sigmoid function:

σ(z)=11+e−z.\sigma(z) = \frac{1}{1 + e^{-z}}.σ(z)=1+e−z1​.
The figure below shows a sigmoid activation function on the left, with the rectified linear (ReLU) activation function on the right for comparison.

1.2.A) What is an expression for the derivative of the sigmoid with respect to zzz, expressed as a function of zzz, its input?

1.2.B) What is an expression for the derivative of the sigmoid with respect to zzz, but this time expressed as a function of o=σ(z)o = \sigma(z)o=σ(z), its output?
Hint: Think about the expression 1−11+e−z1 - \frac{1}{1 + e^{-z}}1−1+e−z1​. (Here is a review of computing derivatives.)

Enter a Python expression (use ** for exponentiation) involving only o (note: eand z are not allowed, and remember o=σ(z)o = \sigma(z)o=σ(z)):
100.00%
You have infinitely many submissions remaining.
Your entry was parsed as:
o×(1−o)o \times \left(1 - o\right)o×(1−o)

In this model, we will consider positive points to have label +1, and negative points to have label 0.

We need a loss function that works well when we are predicting probabilities. A good choice is to ask what probability is assigned to the correct label. We will interpret the value outputted by our classifier as the probability that the example is positive. So, if the output value is aaa and the true label is +1+1+1, then the probability assigned to the true label is aaa; on the other hand, if the true label is 000, then the probability assigned to the true label is 1−a1 - a1−a. Because we actually will be interested in the probability of the predictions on the whole data set, we'd want to choose weights to maximize

∏tP(a(t),y(t))\prod_t P(a^{(t)}, y^{(t)})t∏​P(a(t),y(t))
where P(a(t),y(t))P(a^{(t)}, y^{(t)})P(a(t),y(t)) is the probability that the network predicts the correct label for data point (t)(t)(t).

Using a notational trick (which turns an if expression into a product) that might seem unmotivated now, but will be useful later, we can write the probability P(a,y)P(a, y)P(a,y) as

P(a,y)=ay(1−a)(1−y).P(a, y) = a^y (1 - a)^{(1 - y)}.P(a,y)=ay(1−a)(1−y).

1.2.C) What is the value of P(a,y)P(a, y)P(a,y) when y=0y=0y=0?

Enter an expression for P(a,y)P(a, y)P(a,y) when y=0y=0y=0 in terms of a:

1.2.E) Find a simplified expression for log⁡P(a,y)\log P(a, y)logP(a,y) that does not use exponentiation. Note that we refer to the natural logarithm ln⁡\lnln as log⁡\loglog throughout this assignment, consistent with the lecture notes.

Enter an expression in terms of y and a; you can use log(.) to indicate natural log:
100.00%
You have infinitely many submissions remaining.
Your entry was parsed as:
y×log⁡ea+(1−y)×log⁡e(1−a)y \times \log_{e}{a} + \left(1 - y\right) \times \log_{e}{\left(1 - a\right)}y×loge​a+(1−y)×loge​(1−a)

In fact, because log is a monotonic function, the same weights that maximize the product of the probabilities will minimize the negative log likelihood ("likelihood" is the same as probability; we just use that name here because the phrase is an idiom in machine learning, abbreviated NLL):

Loss(a,y)=NLL(a,y)=−ylog⁡a−(1−y)log⁡(1−a).Loss(a, y) = NLL(a, y) = -y \log a - (1 - y) \log (1 - a).Loss(a,y)=NLL(a,y)=−yloga−(1−y)log(1−a).
Our objective function (over our nnn data points) will then be
∑NLL(a(t),y(t))=−∑t=1n[y(t)log⁡a(t)+(1−y(t))log⁡(1−a(t))].\sum NLL(a^{(t)}, y^{(t)}) = -\sum_{t = 1}^n \left[ y^{(t)} \log a^{(t)} + (1 - y^{(t)}) \log (1 - a^{(t)}) \right] .∑NLL(a(t),y(t))=−t=1∑n​[y(t)loga(t)+(1−y(t))log(1−a(t))].
Remember that a(t)a^{(t)}a(t) is our model's output for training example ttt, and y(t)y^{(t)}y(t) is the true label (+1 or 0).

Now, we can think about a single unit with a sigmoidal activation function, trained to minimize NLL. So, a1L=σ(∑kwk,1Lxk+w0,1L)a_1^L = \sigma(\sum_k w^L_{k,1} x_k + {w_{0,1}^L})a1L​=σ(∑k​wk,1L​xk​+w0,1L​). In this case, we have L=1L = 1L=1.

1.2.G) Write a formula for the gradient of the NLL with respect to the full weight vector, ∇WLNLL(a1L,y)\nabla_{W^L} NLL(a_1^L, y)∇WL​NLL(a1L​,y), for a single training example.

2) Multiclass classification

What if we needed to classify homework problems into three categories: enlightening, boring, impossible? We can do this by using a "one-hot" encoding on the output, and using three output units with what is called a "softmax" (SM) activation module. It's not a typical activation module, since it takes in all nLn_LnL​ pre-activation values zjLz^L_jzjL​ in R\mathbb{R}R and returns nLn_LnL​ output values ajL∈[0,1]a^L_j \in [0, 1]ajL​∈[0,1] such that ∑jajL=1\sum_j a^L_j = 1∑j​ajL​=1. This can be interpreted as representing a probability distribution over the possible categories.

The individual entries are computed as

aj=ezj∑k=1nLezka_j = \frac{e^{z_j}}{\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{n^L} e^{z_k}}aj​=k=1∑nL​ezk​ezj​​
We'll describe the relationship of the vector aaa on the vector zzz as
a=SM(z)a = {\rm SM}(z)a=SM(z)
The network below shows a one-layer network with a linear module followed by a softmax activation module.

2.A) What probability distribution over the categories is represented by zL=[−1,0,1]Tz^L = [-1, 0, 1]^TzL=[−1,0,1]T?

Enter a distribution (a list of three numbers adding up to 1) for the three categories. Your answers should be numeric (please enter numbers, and do not use the symbol eee):
100.00%
You have infinitely many submissions remaining.

Now, we need a loss function Loss(a,y)Loss(a, y)Loss(a,y) where aaa is a discrete probability distribution and yyy is a one-hot vector encoding of a single output value. It makes sense to use negative log likelihood as a loss function for the same reasons as before. So, we'll just extend our definition of NLL from earlier:

NLL(a,y)=−∑j=1nLyjln⁡ajL.NLL(a, y) = -\sum_{j = 1}^{n^L} y_j \ln a^L_j.NLL(a,y)=−j=1∑nL​yj​lnajL​.
Note that the above expression is for multi-classes (number of class &gt;2&gt;2>2). For two-classes, the expression reduce to what you saw after Problem 1.2.E.

2.B) If a=[.3,.5,.2]Ta = [.3, .5, .2]^Ta=[.3,.5,.2]T and y=[0,0,1]Ty = [0, 0, 1]^Ty=[0,0,1]T, what is NLL(a,y)NLL(a, y)NLL(a,y)?

Enter an expression involving log(.) (for natural log) and constants:

You have infinitely many submissions remaining.

−log⁡e.2-\log_{e}{.2}−loge​.2

Now, we can think about a single layer with a softmax activation module, trained to minimize NLL. The pre-activation values (the output of the linear module) are:

zjL=∑kwk,jLxk+w0,jLz^L_j = \sum_k w^L_{k,j} x_k + {w_{0,j}^L}zjL​=k∑​wk,jL​xk​+w0,jL​
and aL=SM(zL)a^L = SM(z^L)aL=SM(zL).

To do gradient descent, we need to know ∂∂wk,jLNLL(aL,y)\frac{\partial}{\partial w^L_{k,j}} NLL(a^L, y)∂wk,jL​∂​NLL(aL,y). We'll reveal the secret (that you might guess from Problem 1) that it has an awesome form! (Please consider deriving this, for fun and satisfaction!)

∂∂wk,jLNLL(aL,y)=xk(ajL−yj)\frac{\partial}{\partial w^L_{k,j}} NLL(a^L, y) = x_k (a^L_j - y_j)∂wk,jL​∂​NLL(aL,y)=xk​(ajL​−yj​)
And of course, it's easy to compute the whole matrix of these derivatives, ∇WLNLL(aL,y)\nabla_{W^L} NLL(a^L, y)∇WL​NLL(aL,y), in one quick matrix computation.

2.C) Suppose we have two input units and three possible output values, and the weight matrix WLW^{L}WL is

WL=[1−1−2−121]W^L = \begin{bmatrix} 1 &amp; -1 &amp; -2 \\ -1 &amp; 2 &amp; 1 \end{bmatrix}WL=[1−1​−12​−21​]
or in Python form: w = np.array([[1, -1, -2], [-1, 2, 1]]).

Assume the biases are zero, the input x=[1,1]Tx = [1, 1]^Tx=[1,1]T (e.g., x = np.array([[1, 1]]).T), and the target output y=[0,1,0]Ty = [0, 1, 0]^Ty=[0,1,0]T (e.g., y = np.array([[0, 1, 0]]).T). 3) Neural Networks

In this problem we will analyze a simple neural network to understand its classification properties. You might find the colab file useful. However, we encourage you to go through all the calculation by hand once, which should be a good practice.

Consider the neural network given in the figure below, with ReLU activation functions (f1f^1f1 in the figure) on all hidden neurons, and softmax activation (f2f^2f2 in the figure) for the output layer, resulting in softmax outputs (a12a^2_1a12​ and a22a^2_2a22​ in the figure).

Given an input x=[x1,x2]Tx = [x_1, x_2]^Tx=[x1​,x2​]T, the hidden units in the network are activated in stages as described by the following equations:

z11=x1w11,1+x2w12,1+w10,1a11=max{z11,0}z12=x1w11,2+x2w12,2+w10,2a12=max{z12,0}z13=x1w11,3+x2w12,3+w10,3a13=max{z13,0}z14=x1w11,4+x2w12,4+w10,4a14=max{z14,0}z11=x1w1,11+x2w2,11+w0,11a11=max{z11,0}z21=x1w1,21+x2w2,21+w0,21a21=max{z21,0}z31=x1w1,31+x2w2,31+w0,31a31=max{z31,0}z41=x1w1,41+x2w2,41+w0,41a41=max{z41,0}
z21=a11w21,1+a12w22,1+a13w23,1+a14w24,1+w20,1z22=a11w21,2+a12w22,2+a13w23,2+a14w24,2+w20,2.z12=a11w1,12+a21w2,12+a31w3,12+a41w4,12+w0,12z22=a11w1,22+a21w2,22+a31w3,22+a41w4,22+w0,22.
The final output of the network is obtained by applying the softmax function to the last hidden layer,
a21=ez21ez21+ez22a22=ez22ez21+ez22.a12=ez12ez12+ez22a22=ez22ez12+ez22.

In this problem, we will consider the following setting of parameters:

[w11,1w11,2w11,3w11,4w12,1w12,2w12,3w12,4]=[10−10010−1],⎡⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎢⎣w10,1w10,2w10,3w10,4⎤⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎥⎦=⎡⎢ ⎢ ⎢⎣−1−1−1−1⎤⎥ ⎥ ⎥⎦,[w1,11w1,21w1,31w1,41w2,11w2,21w2,31w2,41]=[10−10010−1],[w0,11w0,21w0,31w0,41]=[−1−1−1−1], ⎡⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎢ ⎢⎣w21,1w21,2w22,1w22,2w23,1w23,2w24,1w24,2⎤⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎥ ⎥⎦=⎡⎢ ⎢ ⎢⎣1−11−11−11−1⎤⎥ ⎥ ⎥⎦,[w20,1w20,2]=[02].[w1,12w1,22w2,12w2,22w3,12w3,22w4,12w4,22]=[1−11−11−11−1],[w0,12w0,22]=[02].

3.3) Network outputs

In our network above, the output layer with two softmax units is used to classify into one of two classes. For class 1, the first unit's output should be larger than the other unit's output, and for class 2, the second unit's output should be larger. This generalizes nicely to kkk classes by using kkk output units.

(We have previously examined addressing two-class classification problems using a single output unit with a sigmoid activation; this is another way to address them.)

Let's characterize the region in xxx-space where this network's output indicates the first class (that is, a12a^2_1a12​ is larger) or indicates the second class (that is, a22a^2_2a22​ is larger). Your diagram from the previous part will be useful here.
